t: Then*p Job answered the Lord,*s and said,
I*p know that thou canst do every thing, and that no thought can be withholden from thee.
Who*p is he that hideth counsel without knowledge? therefore have I uttered that I understood not; things too wonderful for me, which I knew not.
Hear,*p I beseech thee, and I will speak: I will demand of thee, and declare thou unto me.
I*p have heard of thee by the hearing of the ear: but now mine eye seeth thee.
Wherefore*p I abhor myself, and repent in dust and ashes.

And*p it was so, that after the Lord*s had spoken these words unto Job, the Lord*s said to Eliphaz the Temanite, My wrath is kindled against thee, and against thy two friends: for ye have not spoken of me the thing that is right, as my servant Job hath.

Therefore*p take unto you now seven bullocks and seven rams, and go to my servant Job, and offer up for yourselves a burnt offering; and my servant Job shall pray for you: for him will I accept: lest I deal with you after your folly, in that ye have not spoken of me the thing which is right, like my servant Job.
So*p Eliphaz the Temanite and Bildad the Shuhite and Zophar the Naamathite went, and did according as the Lord*s commanded them: the Lord*s also accepted Job.
And*p the Lord*s turned the captivity of Job, when he prayed for his friends: also the Lord*s gave Job twice as much as he had before.

Then*p came there unto him all his brethren, and all his sisters, and all they that had been of his acquaintance before, and did eat bread with him in his house: and they bemoaned him, and comforted him over all the evil that the Lord*s had brought upon him: every man also gave him a piece of money, and every one an earring of gold.
So*p the Lord*s blessed the latter end of Job more than his beginning: for he had fourteen thousand sheep, and six thousand camels, and a thousand yoke of oxen, and a thousand she asses.
He*p had also seven sons and three daughters.
And*p he called the name of the first, Jemima; and the name of the second, Kezia; and the name of the third, Kerenâ€“happuch.
And*p in all the land were no women found so fair as the daughters of Job: and their father gave them inheritance among their brethren.
After*p this lived Job an hundred and forty years, and saw his sons, and his sons' sons, even four generations.
So*p Job died, being old and full of days.
